content.rendered:
From soft and fuzzy to hard and weird to straight and minimalist, we’ve got you covered this week with work from Bangkok, Paris, and London.

Virgin Daisies by Wide & Narrow

Virgin Daisies is a boutique line of swimwear for women in Bangkok, Thailand. Its identity by local firm Wide & Narrow features an almost obligatory-for-fashion-lines Optima-esque wordmark — one that seems to be either customized or drawn from scratch with a great thin structure and some tiny spiky serifs coming off some of the letters, giving it a bit of a bite. What caught my attention though is the lovely salmon, paint-like texture. I’m not really sure what it means or the concept behind but it looks damn pretty, both on gray (particularly on gray) and white. The embossed sticker is a great touch too. Overall, a very delicate and appropriate feel for the product. See full project here.

Musée Picasso Paris (proposal) by Julien Lelièvre

This is not an implemented identity but, reportedly, the runner-up to a competition to redesign the Musée Picasso Paris, whose current logo is this. The proposed identity by Parisian Julien Lelièvre interprets the art and approach of Pablo Picasso in a non-literal way by creating a family of typefaces united in their hard-angled construction and visually challenging aesthetics. The main typeface would have been a Bell Centennial Bold Listing on steroids and with ink traps that could catch a bear. The result is not “pretty” but it’s extremely bold, graphic, and expressive. It would be amazing to see this carried out in full. The project page is in French and a little hard to follow through Google Translate but worth perusing for the concept and additional type images. See full project (Thanks to Nigel Morley for the tip)

Roots & Bulbs by Robot Food

We now turn our attention to something more normal… With a few locations in London, Roots & Bulbs offers cold pressed organic juices, superfood smoothies, and naturally sourced food. Designed by Leeds-based Robot Food, the identity is minimally typeset in a condensed rounded sans serif that allows the packaging to showcase the densely colored juices. The little patch of grass under the wordmark is enough to add a welcome touch of graphic decoration that literally grounds the type. Simplicity done (and cold-pressed) well! See full project.
